column1: Will a bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) trade on a US exchange before 1 January 2022?
column6: ['Business', 'Finance', 'Technology', 'US Policy']
After a late night shift in position without confirming if EFT in question is speculating on futures, I'm back down the low end.
My rationale is summarized in my prior forecasts.
Teach me to read the clarifications. If ETF futures and derivatives don't count, then this is obviously zero.

This is for bitcoin derivates, futures: "The SEC is poised to allow the first U.S. Bitcoin futures exchange-traded fund to begin trading in a watershed moment for the cryptocurrency industry, according to people familiar with the matter." "Unlike Bitcoin ETF applications that the regulator has previously rejected, the proposals by ProShares and Invesco Ltd. are based on futures contracts and were filed under mutual fund rules that SEC Chairman Gary Gensler has said provide “significant investor protections.” "Four futures-backed Bitcoin ETFs could begin trading on U.S. exchanges this month, with deadlines for applications from VanEck and Valkyrie also approaching."
Still: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-08/wall-street-could-get-four-bitcoin-futures-etfs-by-end-of-month
Too short of a deadline given regulatory timelines, should happen a bit later then that.
The party may not be quite over, but the parents have been called.
There’s been no action on this, and then indications are that the administration is cool in crypto. Lowering my estimate accordingly.
https://cryptopotato.com/sec-could-approve-a-bitcoin-futures-etf-by-october-says-bloomberg-strategist/
https://www.barrons.com/articles/a-bitcoin-etf-is-still-in-the-works-here-are-your-options-in-the-meantime-51618014033 Bitcoin ETFs is still in the works

SEC security Exchange Commission would consider it as a favorable option - Rise of digital transactions towards end of 2021- however concerns from fraud in cryptocurrency space might slow this process - And potential risks of high cost https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/19/experts-say-sec-approval-for-a-bitcoin-etf-wont-happen-any-time-soon.html
Given Bitcoin's volatility, I am skeptical that anything but futures contracts will speculate solely on Bitcoin.
Time elapsed, looks like next year is more likely
https://www.investors.com/news/bitcoin-etfs-sec-approval-cryptocurrency-funds/

In my opinion it's worth noting that the current crowd forecast as I make this prediction is 25%. I know that this crowd are not (yet) Superforecasters and thus are likely to fall prey to various biases which would overestimate the probability. The main one being the correlation between people who think they can predict the future and people who are crypto-zealots. Thus, I would take the crowd estimate as an an unrealistic ceiling and heavily discount that signal even before doing the following fundamental analysis:

"Valkyrie Investments vaulted to the front of the queue for approval from the SEC for the first U.S. Bitcoin exchange-traded fund thanks to a quirk that allows smaller issuers to file confidentially for new offerings."
updating for time elapsed without any changes in favor.
Fidelity has filed paperwork. Gary Genslernisnheading up the SEC. He is highly knowledgeable in crypto currency. I think approval is fairly likely.
Bull.
So far, Canadian financial regulators have approved four bitcoin ETFs.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-08-03/sec-s-gensler-signals-pathway-for-a-bitcoin-etf-with-tough-rules https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/03/what-the-sec-chairs-comments-on-crypto-mean-for-a-possible-bitcoin-etf.html https://www.bloomberg.com/professional/blog/etf-approval-times-shortened-costs-slashed-sec-2019-plan/
No. The SEC doesn't care they are behind Canada etc. They are walking going slowly.
Reducing further as there doesn't seem to be forward movement and time is running out. https://www.wsj.com/articles/wall-street-watchdog-keeps-bitcoin-etfs-on-ice-11626616801

More volatility on July 4 - mirroring prior weekend sell offs - is likely one of the more serious nails in the coffin of this one as of late; That type of volatility during weekend swings leaves ETF investors vulnerable in that they will either be exposed to continued losses until markets open or will be forced to hold until open - all of which could make or break individual "fortunes" (potentially) on nothing more than certain speculative whims.

I did not appreciate all of the work that the SEC has done on this topic already. And I did not know just how many EFT applications had already been submitted to the SEC. Also, Canada recently started approving crypto-EFTs. With these things in mind, I think it's more likely than not, but still hard to predict.

Yes; With China already rapidly moving forward with e-CNY US really have to either do major kowtows to decentralized crypto, or be forever behind. Bitcon will likely be first, as the most established crypto
so maybe i was too optimistic on this. no special insight here so market consensus it is

The SEC once again delayed its decision saying it wants more public comments and citing worries about volatility and lack of oversight/regulation. Bitcoing price has perhaps been as stable as it can be hovering between 35K and barely reaching $40K in the past few weeks. There were some increases following the Miami convention, the announcement by El Salvador's decision, and news bits like Elon Musk saying Tesla will once again accept it as it gets more green energy alternatives, and Miami's mayor saying he's looking into accessing nuclear power for mining. All sound to be like desperate measures to pump the price which has failed by Bitcoin standards. Retail investors continue to see loses. Any attempt at manipulating the price to give a semblance of stability in order to get points with SEC is also failing. Looks like there are still too many major, basic matters to take into account for approval to happen in the next 6 months

I was already wavering on this question, but now the crowd is confirming my concern. It's much more likely that a Crypto ETF be approved than a pure Bitcoin one. With the recent volatility, it's looking far less likely.

Bitcoin is struggling, even efforts by Elon Musk this week (meeting with Bitcoin Miners "Council"), and targeted headlines (like Ray Dalio saying he's bought Bitcoin and he'd rather own bitcoin than bonds) have failed to pump the price. It hovers around $40,000 then goes back down to ~$36,000). Bitcoin is not coming back fast enough from Musk's tweets on energy consumption, China's banning of miners, and most recently the Fed and bank regulators saying they are evaluating crypto policy.

In light of the recent volatility, it seems likely now that the SEC can and will keep delaying any ETFs this year. The SEC is being very cautious about this in ETF form, without the capacity-restriction guardrails that mutual funds have, and the SEC is closely monitoring the mutual funds and warning investors about cryptocurrency: https://www.ft.com/content/c36013a0-65a9-4f1c-901d-314577cc5266 The expert quoted in that article does not think it's likely that anything will be approved this year.
https://www.coindesk.com/bloomberg-analyst-bitcoin-etf-2021

BTC has not matured enough as a concept to invoke the confidence required for me to expect a broad acceptance amongst SEC governors in regards to any ETF related filings. While sentiment towards cryptocurrency remains positive - especially in regards to it's potential to become a standard currency in the not to distant future - so many flaws persist in the valuation of each bitcoin share; Elon musk tweets one tweet reiterating a decision made by one company (Tesla) in regards to their BTC holdings and you see bears running away with it (Down over $10K per share last 24-48-hours).
https://www.coindesk.com/bloomberg-analyst-bitcoin-etf-2021 seems like we're getting there. Any statements from the SEC on this?

Crowd seems super confident probably following Canada's approval and that in recent history bitcoin price has moved just one way in recent times. There is a lot of lobbying going on/ many have applied to the sec for approval.
There are already substantial moves by various financial institutions including PayPal and BNY Mellon to integrate crypto into the mainstream.
SEC delays decision on approving bitcoin ETF
Somewhat more optimistic on this front.

I'm being risky and re-affirming. VanEck filed an application recently but I have little faith for 2021. The SEC is fearful of volatility so may want some extra time to let a price point settle just a little.
Canada’s largest digital-asset investment fund manager 3iQ Corp. is hoping to raise more than $200 million by listing its Bitcoin exchange-traded fund in Dubai

Dado que Gary Gensler, profesor de Bitcoin y Blockchain en el MIT, fue nombrado presidente de la SEC por el Senado de EE.UU, tener un importante actor pro crypto dentro de la SEC da el preludio de que será posible tener un ETF de bitcoin dentro de su territorio. Además se suma el éxito que tuvo que Canadá el cual fue el primer país de América del Norte que aprobó un ETF de Bitcoin, siendo los resultados muy favorables. En dos meses ha logrado acumular un valor de más de 1.100 millones de dólares en activos bajo inversión. Una cifra que demuestra el interés y demanda potencial de los inversores por este tipo de instrumento financiero.
Demand.
China's cryptocurrency launch is putting the pressure on other cryptocurrencies.

https://www.coindesk.com/sec-vaneck-bitcoin-etf-2021 VanEck filed for the ETF with Cboe BZX Exchange earlier this year, with Cboe publishing the 19b-4 at the beginning of March. Once the document is published in the Federal Register (the nation’s logbook), the general public will have 21 days to submit comments on the SEC’s portal. The SEC can extend the review period up to 240 days before it has to make a final decision. When evaluating past applications, it has always extended these decisions to their full time limit.

https://www.investing.com/news/cryptocurrency-news/asset-management-firm-fidelity-seeks-sec-approval-to-launch-a-bitcoin-etf-2459019 News moving in the expected direction. No knowledge about SEC authorisation process or any of the next steps involved but given interest it seems 90% is a good estimate of regulatory inability to postpone this until 2022.
Goldman-Sachs is anticipating acceptance of BC among investors with their announcement of a digital assets group within their private wealth management team.

I am increasing my odds to "in favor" due to the ETF application submitted to the SEC by Fidelity - as well as another by Vanguard - who are reputable institutions which may add more weight to the approval process if the SEC believes them capable of navigating the complexities required for managing such a fund.

Based on these two stories I would put it at 90% at this point: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/24/fidelity-to-launch-bitcoin-etf-as-investment-giant-builds-its-digital-asset-business-.html Fidelity launching a bitcoin ETF is a big deal. Like Vanguard, they are as legit as they come.

In Europe there are already Bitcoin ETF's (for example BTCE). With the crowd adopting Bitcoin and Blockchain related assets very fast, it is a matter of time before this will be tradeable in the US as well.

Da es inzwischen schon Fondsgesellschaften gibt die Bitcoin Investmentfonds auflegen und aufgrund der medialen Berichterstattung über Bitcoin & Co steigt wird es bald einen Index auf Kryptowährungen geben. Daher wird es auch zeitnah die Möglichkeit für einen ETF geben und dieses Instrument aufgrund der Nachfrage der breiten Masse gelauncht werden.

This one, the Valkyrie Innovative Balance Sheet ETF, seems highly likely to be approved: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1593547/000139834421006410/fp0063501_485apos.htm It's an ETF that is indirectly a bitcoin ETF by holding companies that have bitcoin in their balance sheets. I'm not sure whether it would trigger a yes in this question (maybe I should ask for clarification).

Aljazeera - "Cboe in a Monday filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission sought the green light for the VanEck Bitcoin Trust. VanEck Associates Corp. in December applied to start an ETF tracking the largest cryptocurrency. It is at least the third time since 2018 that Cboe has teamed with VanEck to seek a fund approval"

I'm bumping my forecast up a bit b/c Coinbase is supposed to go public in the next few months and I think that will start to normalize public crypto trading in the US. It also could go spectacularly poorly, loose a bunch of value and highlight the speculative nature of crypto currency (which is not really functioning like a currency anyway more an asset like gold) But I think it won't go that poorly, I think having a shares in a crypto exchange trading publicly will make it more likely that the SEC approves a bitcoin ETF https://www.coindesk.com/coinbase-s-1-trust-markets
New SEC & Canadian ETFs
Not happening in a post-GameStop environment.
Canadian regulators go comfortable. Expect US will as well.... absent some massive drop or spike in BTC (which is possible).

The reluctance of the SEC to authorize a Bitcoin related security ETF appears to be based on two primary factors: adequate regulatory framework to prevent currency/market manipulation, and the overall size of cryptocurrency market (currently sitting at around $50K per share).

I don't have a great numerical base rate here. But I'm basing my thinking on the fact that several ETFs have applied and been denied by the SEC in the last few years. So the going in argument is that no, it won't get approved. The next question is why did those other ETFs not get approved and what has changed since then that makes the applications in 2021 different. I found this article helpful in explaining in plain English why the SEC hasn't approved one yet "The regulatory body has refused to approve such a product on the grounds that it's uncomfortable with the risk involved in an unregulated product in an ETF wrapper. It's also worried that a bitcoin ETF would result in a rush of investors not fully understanding what they're buying" https://www.thestreet.com/etffocus/market-intelligence/vaneck-launch-bitcoin-etf-again#:~:text=The%20regulatory%20body%20has%20refused,product%20in%20an%20ETF%20wrapper.&text=The%20coin%2Dbased%20funds%20were,about%20the%20futures%2Dbased%20products.
"Will government do X by [Date]?" Probably not. On the other hand, Canada has a bitcoin ETF as of 5 days ago, which has been a hit so far: https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/quote/BTCC-B.TO/

I'm somewhat out of my depth here so some bullets to structure my reasoning arround * absence (so far) of BTC in ETF provides opportunity for listed corps to invest in BTC and offer themselves as a play on it * banks, fund managers,... are getting swamped with regular joe's calling in to get a piece of the BTC-pie * likely some more corps will announce over the next couple of weeks a play on BTC (apple wallet, others?) so expect the momentum to increase a little bit more * wave of new investment is at least somewhat tied to Matt Levine's "boredom hypothesis"; once economy is fully up and running again, expect some of that money to be spent rather than sit in investment/crypto-accounts So that's kinda of the demand side.
https://www.forexlive.com/Cryptocurrency/!/success-of-canadian-bitcoin-etf-highlights-the-bull-case-20210219
I’m behind the bubble.
Can buy and sell options for Bitcoin? Can you leverage Bitcoin? Can governments issue Bitcoin debt? Who can issue bitcoins CDO’s?

Those in the crypto community who are optimistic that Gensler will significantly reimagine the SEC’s approach to regulating digital assets are likely to be disappointed. In particular, we believe there is a low probability that he will revisit the SEC’s fundamental approach to treating most digital assets as securities under the Howey test. Gensler’s resume as a regulator shows he tends to favor more regulation, not less, and he will likely feel political pressure to continue this approach at the SEC.

A couple considerations: There have already been several attempts at establishing Bitcoin ETFs over the years, all struck down. The interest by institutional investors in the space can't be understated. It is not retail investors but institutional investors that will allow this asset to flourish in the mainstream and lead to further financial instruments being created around it (i.e. an ETF) I think a Bitcoin ETF will eventually emerge, the trouble here is timing. There are some already in the pipeline but as others have mentioned, economic tailwinds could also show the weakness of bitcoin, casting it to the fringes once again.
Quite possibly, but the volatility of BTC makes for a very unique investment tool. Knowing how and where it fits in a portfolio could be a challenge.
The news just reported the price of bitcoin just went went to 52,142.50

Current investment firms are taking a larger interest in Bitcoin as it gains in value. Blackrock added bitcoin futures trading and Tesla added $1.5 billion in Bitcoin value [1]. Additionally, Canada has just approved the first Bitcoin ETF to trade in North America, and speculators believe this could be a stepping stone to approval by the SEC [2].

It's a matter of the SEC approving it, NYDIG has filed for it and is expecting to hold $25B in Bitcoin for their institutional clients by the end of the year. Morgan Stanley (Counterpoint Global $150B fund) and JP Morgan's decision on Bitcoin will be a good sign on how fast this is going to move. Big players like Tesla going in keeps driving the price up but what happens next? There's a chance they will keep watching the price to a certain point and then cash in which would delay wide Wall St acceptance of Bitcoin as an asset class. It's a matter of time. Need to look into how Wall St and the SEC would consider the market ready enough for it.
A very high probability that the IRS, SEC and major exchanges will agree on ‘regulatory standards’ for an array of cryptocurrencies.
